flashcards.definition: The uppermost layer of soil, rich in organic matter and nutrients.
The layer of soil beneath the topsoil, less fertile and with more mineral deposits.
The solid rock layer beneath the soil horizons.
Decomposed organic matter in soil, providing nutrients and improving structure.
Fine-grained soil particles that retain water and nutrients.
Medium-sized soil particles, between sand and clay in size.
Coarse-grained soil particles that allow for good drainage.
A balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay, considered ideal for plant growth.
A vertical section of soil showing the different layers or horizons.
A distinct layer of soil within a soil profile.
The breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller particles.
The process of soil being carried away by wind, water, or other agents.
The removal of soluble substances from soil by percolating water.
The relative proportion of sand, silt, and clay in a soil.
The arrangement of soil particles into aggregates.
The original rock or mineral from which soil is formed.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of soil.
Minerals and organic compounds in soil that are essential for plant growth.
Decomposed plant and animal material in soil.
The compression of soil, reducing pore space and water infiltration.
The amount of pore space in soil, affecting water and air movement.
The ability of water to move through soil.
Practices used to protect soil from erosion and degradation.
Natural or synthetic material added to soil to provide nutrients for plants.
The breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms.
The study of soil.
The decline in soil quality due to various factors.
The concentration of soluble salts in soil.
The upper level of underground water saturation.
The ability of water to move upward in soil against gravity.
The area of soil where plant roots grow and absorb nutrients.
Essential elements needed in large amounts by plants (e.g., Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium).
Essential elements needed in small amounts by plants (e.g., Iron, Zinc, Copper).
The study of living organisms in the soil.
A material added to soil to improve its properties.
An agricultural technique that avoids tilling the soil.
Plowing and planting crops along the contour lines of sloping land.
Creating level platforms on slopes to reduce erosion.
A crop planted primarily to improve soil health.
The practice of planting different crops in the same area in a planned sequence.
Analyzing a soil sample to determine its nutrient content, pH, and other properties.
A systematic examination, description, classification, and mapping of soils in a given area.
A U.S. federal agency dedicated to the conservation of natural resources. (Now called the Natural Resources Conservation Service)
The surface layer of soil composed of organic matter.
The topsoil layer, rich in organic matter and minerals.
The subsoil layer, less fertile than the topsoil.
The weathered parent material layer.
A zone of leaching found in some soil profiles.
The removal of a thin layer of topsoil by rainfall and runoff.
The removal of soil by concentrated water flowing through a channel.
The removal of soil by small, shallow channels.
The removal of soil particles by wind.
The process of identifying and delineating different soil types on a map.
The ability of soil aggregates to resist breakdown.
The ability of soil to retain water.
The amount of water a soil can hold against gravity.
The soil moisture level at which plants can no longer extract water.
The amount of water in soil that plants can readily use.
The mass of dry soil per unit volume.
The mass of solid soil particles per unit volume.
The use of living organisms to clean up contaminated soil.
The use of plants to clean up contaminated soil.
The process of salt accumulation in soil.
The saturation of soil with water.
Lacking free oxygen.
A layer of soil that is parallel to the soil surface and has distinct characteristics.
The uppermost layer of soil, rich in organic matter and nutrients.
The layer of soil beneath topsoil, often containing more clay and less organic matter.
The solid rock underlying soil.
Decomposed organic matter in soil.
The breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller particles.
The process of soil being moved from one place to another by wind or water.
The proportion of sand, silt, and clay in a soil.
The arrangement of soil particles into aggregates.
The amount of pore space in a soil.
The ability of water to move through soil.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a soil.
The smallest mineral particle in soil.
A medium-sized mineral particle in soil.
The largest mineral particle in soil.
A soil with a balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay.
The underlying geological material from which soil is formed.
A vertical section of soil showing all its horizons.
The movement and exchange of organic and inorganic matter back into the production of living matter.
The process of water carrying dissolved substances down through the soil.
The compression of soil, reducing pore space.
Practices used to protect soil from erosion and degradation.
A crop planted primarily to protect soil from erosion.
A farming technique that avoids plowing the soil.
Creating level platforms on slopes to reduce soil erosion.
Planting different crops in a sequence to improve soil health.
Plowing across a slope following its elevation contour lines.
Any material added to soil to improve its physical or chemical properties.
Any material in soil that was once living.
The process by which organic matter is broken down.
The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into forms usable by plants.
The conversion of nitrates in soil to nitrogen gas.
A symbiotic association between a fungus and the roots of a plant.
The study of living organisms in the soil.
A cluster of soil particles held together by organic matter or other binding agents.
The ability of water to move upwards through soil pores.
The point at which plants can no longer extract water from the soil.
The amount of water a soil can hold after excess water has drained away.
The saturation of soil with water.
The accumulation of salts in the soil.
Precipitation that is abnormally acidic, affecting soil pH.
Metallic elements with a high density that can contaminate soil.
The accumulation of substances, such as pesticides, in an organism.
The use of plants to remove pollutants from soil.
The decline in soil quality.
The process by which fertile land becomes desert.
Farming practices that maintain soil health for future generations.
Decomposed organic matter used as a soil amendment.
Compost produced by earthworms.
A crop specifically grown and then plowed into the soil to improve its fertility.
The zone of soil surrounding plant roots.
The systematic categorization of soils based on their properties.
Land suitable for growing crops.
The process of creating maps showing the distribution of different soil types.
The release of carbon dioxide from the soil as a result of decomposition and other processes.
Ped: Naturally occurring aggregate of soil particles.
The mass of dry soil per unit volume of soil.
The mass per unit volume of the soil solids.
The amount of water that a given soil can hold.
The capacity of a soil to hold exchangeable cations.
The percentage of the soil's CEC occupied by basic cations (e.g., Ca, Mg, K, Na).
Nutrients required for plant growth.
Nutrients required in large quantities by plants.
Nutrients required in small quantities by plants.
Plant growth is limited by the nutrient that is most deficient.
The capacity of a soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.
The amount of water in the soil that plants can readily access.
The rate at which water enters the soil.
The carbon stored in soil organic matter.
The complex network of organisms that live in the soil and interact with each other.
The benefits that humans receive from ecosystems, including soil.
A US governmental agency focused on soil health, now called the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS).
The layer of unconsolidated rocky material covering bedrock.
A hierarchical system for classifying soils.
A soil horizon with specific properties used for soil classification.
A system for rating the suitability of land for agriculture.
A systematic examination, description, classification, and mapping of soils in a given area.
A permeable fabric used to stabilize soil and prevent erosion.
An area of vegetation near a body of water to filter pollutants and prevent erosion.
The preparation of land for growing crops.
A conservation tillage practice where only a narrow strip of soil is tilled.
A conservation tillage practice where crops are planted on ridges.
A farming system where machinery traffic is confined to permanent paths to reduce soil compaction.
The compression of soil, resulting in decreased pore space and reduced water infiltration.
A hardened layer on the soil surface that can impede seedling emergence.
A small channel formed by concentrated water flow that is easily filled in by tillage.
Small channels formed by concentrated water flow that are easily removed by tillage.
Larger channels formed by concentrated water flow that cannot be removed by tillage.
The uniform removal of soil from the land surface by water or wind.
The detachment and movement of soil particles by the impact of raindrops.
The detachment and movement of soil particles by wind.
The susceptibility of a soil to erosion.
Practices used to reduce soil erosion.
A row of trees or shrubs planted to protect soil from wind erosion.
The deposition of soil particles that have been eroded.
A soil with a high concentration of soluble salts.
A soil with a high proportion of sodium ions.
A soil containing a significant amount of calcium carbonate.
A soil that contains sulfuric acid, typically formed in coastal areas.
Soil composed mainly of organic matter; peat or muck.
Soil with permafrost within two meters of the surface.
Soil formed in volcanic ash.
Highly weathered soil with low fertility; typically found in tropical regions.
Soil with a high clay content that shrinks and swells dramatically with changes in moisture content.
Highly weathered soil with low base saturation; typically found in humid, subtropical regions.
Acidic soil with a distinct layer of accumulated organic matter and iron/aluminum oxides.
Moderately weathered soil with moderate base saturation.
Soil with a thick, dark topsoil rich in organic matter; typically found in grasslands.
Soil showing only moderate soil profile development.
Recently formed soil with little to no soil profile development.
Soil which is weakly developed unconsolidated material.
A soil consisting of little more than rock fragments.
Soil whose properties have been substantially altered by human activities.
Soil that contains significant amounts of man-made materials.
Partially decomposed plant matter accumulated in waterlogged conditions.
Highly decomposed organic soil.
A positively charged ion.
A negatively charged ion.
The ability of a soil to resist changes in pH.
A soil amendment used to raise pH.
A soil amendment used to lower pH.
Nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium - the three primary macronutrients for plants.
A substance added to soil to provide nutrients for plants.
Fertilizer derived from plant or animal matter.
Fertilizer made from synthetic or mineral sources.
Fertilizer that releases nutrients gradually over time.
The analysis of soil to determine its nutrient content and other properties.
A person who provides education and assistance to farmers and other land managers.
A professional who studies the formation, classification, mapping, and use of soils.
A professional who studies crop production and soil management.
A professional who provides expert advice and services to farmers and other land managers.
A person or organization that has an interest in the management of land and soil.
A person who makes decisions about land and soil management at the local, state, or federal level.
The level of understanding and concern about land and soil issues among the general public.
The process of teaching and learning about land and soil science.
The systematic investigation into land and soil science.
The development and implementation of new technologies and practices for land and soil management.
The cooperation between different individuals and organizations to achieve common goals in land and soil management.
The responsible management of land and soil for the benefit of present and future generations.
The way in which land is used, such as for agriculture, forestry, or urban development.
The practices used to manage land, such as soil conservation, water management, and vegetation management.
Rules and laws that govern the use and management of land and soil.
Financial or other rewards offered to encourage good land and soil management practices.
The ability to meet the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
Long-term changes in temperature and weather patterns, which can affect land and soil.
Sources of water that can be used for irrigation and other purposes.
The variety of life in a particular habitat or ecosystem.
The availability of sufficient food to meet the needs of a population.
Protecting the environment from pollution and other harmful impacts.
An area of land that drains into a common body of water.
A flat area of land adjacent to a river or stream that is subject to flooding.
An area of land that is saturated with water for at least part of the year.
The area of land adjacent to a stream or river.
The process of evaluating the physical, chemical, and biological properties of soil to determine its overall health.
A measurable variable that can be used to assess soil health.
The regular collection of data on soil health indicators.
The process of interpreting data on soil health indicators.
The communication of information on soil health to stakeholders.
A process of continually adjusting management practices based on monitoring and evaluation.
Practices that are designed to protect water quality and soil health.
The use of technology to manage crops and soil more efficiently.
The use of sensors to collect data from a distance.
A computer system that can store, analyze, and display spatial data.
A satellite-based navigation system that can be used to determine the location of features on the Earth's surface.
The application of fertilizer or other inputs at different rates depending on the specific needs of the crop and soil.
The process of creating maps showing the yield of crops in different areas of a field.
Large datasets that can be used to analyze trends and patterns in land and soil.
The use of computer systems to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.
A type of AI that allows computer systems to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.
A decentralized, distributed ledger technology that can be used to track and manage data on land and soil.
A set of 17 goals adopted by the United Nations to achieve a more sustainable future.
An international agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.
An international agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
An international treaty to conserve biodiversity.

flashcards.term: United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification
flashcards.definition: An international treaty to combat desertification.
An annual event held on December 5 to raise awareness about the importance of soil.
A year-long campaign in 2015 to raise awareness about the importance of soil.
A partnership of governments, organizations, and individuals working to promote sustainable soil management.
A United Nations agency that works to improve food security and agricultural productivity.
A United Nations agency that works to protect the environment.
An international financial institution that provides loans to developing countries for development projects.
An international financial institution that works to promote global monetary cooperation and financial stability.
An international organization that regulates international trade.
A political and economic union of 27 member states located primarily in Europe.
A continental union consisting of 55 member states located in Africa.
A political and economic union of 10 member states located in Southeast Asia.

flashcards.term: South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC)
flashcards.definition: A regional intergovernmental organization and geopolitical union in South Asia.

flashcards.term: Latin American and Caribbean Economic System (SELA)
flashcards.definition: A regional organization of Latin American and Caribbean states.
An association of five major emerging economies: Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa.
An intergovernmental political forum consisting of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.
An international forum consisting of 19 countries and the European Union.
An international organisation that works to build better policies for better lives.
A non-profit organization that operates independently of governments.
The aggregate of non-governmental organizations and institutions that manifest interests and will of citizens.
Justice in terms of the distribution of wealth, opportunities, and privileges within a society.

The fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, color, national origin, or income, with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and policies.

The process of working collaboratively with groups of people who are affiliated by geographic proximity, special interests, or similar situations with respect to addressing issues affecting their well-being.

The process by which individuals and organizations obtain, improve, and retain the skills, knowledge, tools, equipment, and other resources needed to do their jobs competently or to a greater capacity.
The process of sharing knowledge from one individual or organization to another.
The process of transferring technology from one individual or organization to another.
Educational services provided to farmers and other land managers to help them improve their practices.
Educational programs designed to provide individuals with the skills and knowledge they need to manage land and soil sustainably.
Public education campaigns designed to raise awareness about the importance of land and soil.
Approaches that involve stakeholders in the decision-making process.
Approaches that consider all aspects of land and soil management, including environmental, social, and economic factors.
Approaches that consider the whole system, rather than just individual parts.
The ability of a system to adjust to changing conditions.
The ability of a system to recover from disturbance.
The degree to which a system is susceptible to harm from exposure to stresses.
The process of identifying and evaluating potential risks.
The process of taking steps to reduce risks.
The process of developing plans to deal with unexpected events.
The process of preparing for disasters.
The actions taken in response to a disaster.
The process of recovering from a disaster.
Agricultural practices that increase productivity, enhance resilience to climate change, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The process of capturing and storing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
A charcoal-like substance produced from biomass that can be used as a soil amendment.
A system of farming principles and practices that increases biodiversity, enriches soils, improves watersheds, and enhances ecosystem services.
Crops that live for more than two years.
The integration of trees and shrubs into agricultural systems.
The practice of grazing livestock in forests or woodlands.
A set of farming practices that minimize soil disturbance, maintain soil cover, and promote crop diversity.
A system of pest control that uses a variety of methods to minimize the use of pesticides.
A system of nutrient management that uses a variety of methods to optimize nutrient use and minimize environmental impacts.
The collection and storage of rainwater or runoff for later use.
Crops that are able to survive and produce yields under drought conditions.
Crops that are able to survive and produce yields in saline soils.
The use of computer models to simulate the climate system.
The process of developing different scenarios for the future based on different assumptions.
The process of assessing the vulnerability of a system to climate change.
The process of developing plans to adapt to climate change.
The process of developing plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The total amount of greenhouse gases emitted by a person, organization, event, or product.
A method for assessing the environmental impacts of a product or service throughout its entire life cycle.
A system for managing the environmental aspects of an organization's operations.

A systematic, documented, periodic and objective evaluation of how well environmental organization, management and equipment are performing with the aim of helping to safeguard the environment and human health.
The use of goods and services that meet basic needs and minimize environmental impacts.
The production of goods and services that minimize environmental impacts and social costs.
A company's commitment to operate in an ethical and sustainable manner.
The practice of making false or misleading claims about the environmental benefits of a product or service.
The practice of providing information to consumers about the environmental impacts of a product or service.
The process of verifying that a product or service meets certain environmental standards.
Investing in companies or projects that are environmentally and socially responsible.
Investing in companies or projects that are consistent with ethical principles.
Investing in companies or projects that are socially responsible.
Investing in companies or projects that are designed to generate social and environmental impact alongside financial returns.
Bonds that are used to finance projects that have environmental benefits.
Projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions to compensate for emissions that occur elsewhere.
Tradable instruments that represent a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.
A system for regulating greenhouse gas emissions by setting a cap on emissions and allowing companies to trade emission allowances.
A tax on greenhouse gas emissions.
Financial assistance provided by governments to support certain activities.
Financial or other rewards offered to encourage certain activities.
Rules and laws that govern certain activities.
Agreed-upon criteria for measuring and evaluating performance.
Techniques or methodologies that, through experience and research, have reliably led to desired results.
Sets of rules outlining the responsibilities of, or proper practices for, an individual, party or organization.
Documentation authenticating that someone has specific knowledge, experience, or skills related to a certain activity or profession.
A formal, independent verification that the quality of a particular project or product meets specified technical standards or requirements.
A measurement of the quality of an organization's policies, products, programs, strategies, and other such measures against those of other organizations.
The process of actively engaging with stakeholders to understand their needs and concerns.
The quality of being open and honest.
The obligation to answer for one's actions.
A process by which local communities are empowered to manage their natural resources sustainably.
A process by which local communities are involved in the planning and implementation of development projects.
Development that is driven by local communities.
Development that is driven by governments or international organizations.
Livelihoods that are environmentally, economically, and socially sustainable.
The right of peoples to healthy and culturally appropriate food produced through ecologically sound and sustainable methods, and their right to define their own food and agriculture systems.
The system of rights and responsibilities that governs the ownership and use of land.
The redistribution of land from large landowners to landless peasants.
The rights to own and use property.
Resources that are difficult to exclude people from using, but whose use by one person reduces its availability to others.
A situation in which individuals acting independently and rationally consult their own self-interest behave contrary to the best interests of the whole group by depleting some common resource.
A system of managing natural resources in which different stakeholders cooperate to achieve common goals.
A system of managing natural resources in which management practices are continually adjusted based on monitoring and evaluation.

An environmental management approach that recognizes the full array of interactions within an ecosystem, including humans, rather than considering single issues, species, or ecosystem services in isolation.

A process that promotes the coordinated development and management of water, land, and related resources in order to maximize the resultant economic and social welfare in an equitable manner without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems.
The management of water resources that cross national boundaries.

The availability of an acceptable quantity and quality of water for health, livelihoods, ecosystems, and production, coupled with an acceptable level of water-related risks to people, environments, and economies.
The interconnectedness of food, energy, and water systems.
A systematic process of identifying and evaluating the potential environmental impacts of a proposed project or policy.
A systematic process of evaluating the environmental impacts of proposed policies, plans, and programs.
A systematic process of evaluating the sustainability of a proposed project or policy.
A systematic process of comparing the costs and benefits of a proposed project or policy.
A decision-making tool that allows for the consideration of multiple criteria, both quantitative and qualitative.
Computer-based systems that support decision-making.
Computer systems that mimic the decision-making abilities of human experts.
A branch of statistics that deals with spatial data.
The analysis of spatial data.
The acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon without making physical contact with it.
A computer system that can store, analyze, and display spatial data.
A satellite-based navigation system that can be used to determine the location of features on the Earth's surface.
Aircraft without a human pilot on board.
Unmanned aerial vehicles.
Devices that detect and measure physical quantities.
The process of examining large and varied data sets to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, market trends, customer preferences and other useful information.
The practice of using a network of remote servers hosted on the Internet to store, manage, and process data, rather than a local server or a personal computer.
The network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet.

The theory and development of computer systems able to perform tasks that normally require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and translation between languages.
An application of artificial intelligence (AI) that provides systems the ability to automatically learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed.
A type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks with multiple layers to analyze data.
A computer system modeled on the human brain and nervous system.
A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots.
The use of machines to automate tasks.
A farming management concept based on observing, measuring and responding to inter and intra-field variability in crops.
A farming management concept using information and communication technologies (ICTs) to optimize and automate agricultural processes.
A farming management concept leveraging digital technologies and data to improve agricultural productivity and sustainability.
The practice of growing crops in vertically stacked layers, often indoors and under controlled conditions.
A system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish or other aquatic creatures supplies the nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water.
A method of growing plants without soil, using mineral nutrient solutions in water.
A method of growing plants without soil, where roots are suspended in air and periodically sprayed with nutrient solutions.
A technology-based approach toward food production. The aim of CEA is to protect the plant and optimize growing conditions.
Organisms whose genetic material has been altered using genetic engineering techniques.
A group of technologies that give scientists the ability to change an organism's DNA.
A gene-editing technology that allows scientists to easily and precisely edit DNA.
The application of engineering principles to biological systems.
The exploitation of biological processes for industrial and other purposes, especially the genetic manipulation of microorganisms for the production of antibiotics, hormones, etc.
The design and construction of new biological parts, devices, and systems, or the re-design of existing natural biological systems for useful purposes.
A fuel derived from living matter.
Plastics made from renewable biomass sources, such as vegetable fats and oils, corn starch, or microorganisms.
Plastics that can be broken down by microorganisms.
Plastics that can be broken down in a compost pile.
The design of chemical products and processes that reduce or eliminate the use or generation of hazardous substances.
An economic system aimed at eliminating waste and the continual use of resources.
The use of goods and services that meet basic needs and minimize environmental impacts, and the production of goods and services that minimize environmental impacts and social costs.
A collection of 17 interlinked global goals designed to be a "blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all".
An international agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.
An international treaty to conserve biodiversity.

flashcards.term: United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD)
flashcards.definition: An international treaty to combat desertification.

flashcards.term: Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction
flashcards.definition: A global framework for reducing disaster risk.
A UN document intended to be a guide for sustainable urban development.
A set of Sustainable Development Goals set out in the 2015 United Nations Resolution 70/1.

A state whereby the amount and quality of land resources necessary to support ecosystem functions and services and enhance food security remain stable or increase within specified temporal and spatial scales and ecosystems.
The process of assisting the recovery of an ecosystem that has been degraded, damaged, or destroyed.
The establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover.
The re-establishment of forest cover, either naturally (through natural regeneration) or artificially (through planting of trees).

The stewardship and use of forests and forest lands in a way, and at a rate, that maintains their biodiversity, productivity, regeneration capacity, vitality and their potential to fulfill, now and in the future, relevant ecological, economic and social functions, at local, national, and global levels, and that does not cause damage to other ecosystems.
Carefully planned and controlled harvesting techniques to minimize damage to forest ecosystems.
Independent verification and labeling of forest products to indicate they originate from sustainably managed forests.
Tracks forest products from the forest to the final consumer to ensure they come from certified sources.
Local communities play a significant role in managing and utilizing forest resources.
The knowledge, innovations, and practices of indigenous and local communities embodying traditional lifestyles relevant for conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity.
The evolving knowledge acquired by indigenous and local peoples over hundreds or thousands of years through direct contact with the environment.
Tourism directed toward natural environments, intended to support conservation efforts and observe wildlife.
Agriculture-based tourism that includes farms, ranches, and wineries.
Tourism that takes full account of its current and future economic, social and environmental impacts, addressing the needs of visitors, the industry, the environment and host communities.
The number of people, other living organisms, or crops that a region can support without environmental degradation.
The impact of a person or community on the environment, expressed as the amount of land required to sustain their use of natural resources.
A concept involving Earth system processes that contain environmental boundaries, proposed in 2009 by a group of Earth system scientists led by Johan Rockström from the Stockholm Resilience Centre.
Critical thresholds in the Earth system, when crossed, can lead to abrupt and irreversible changes.
The capacity for socio-ecological systems to cope with hazardous climate-related events or trends, responding or reorganizing in ways that maintain their essential function, identity, and structure.
The capacity of water systems to function so that human well-being and livelihoods, biodiversity, and economies continue to develop and flourish, in the face of water-related hazards and change.
The capacity over time of a food system and its units at multiple levels, to provide sufficient, appropriate and accessible food to all, even in the face of shocks and long-term stresses.
Adaptation that changes the fundamental attributes of social-ecological systems in anticipation of climate change and its impacts.
Actions that may lead to increased risk of adverse climate-related outcomes, increased vulnerability to climate change, or diminished welfare, now or in the future.
The adverse effects of climate change that cannot be avoided through mitigation or adaptation measures.
The concept that those who are least responsible for climate change suffer its gravest consequences.
The principle that future generations should have the same opportunities and rights as current generations.
A strategy for approaching issues of potential harm when extensive scientific knowledge on the matter is lacking.
The commonly accepted practice that those who produce pollution should bear the costs of managing it to prevent damage to human health or the environment.
A partnership between farmers and consumers in which consumers purchase a share of the farm's harvest in advance.
A market where farmers sell their produce directly to consumers.
Food that is grown and produced within a defined geographic area.
A global movement that promotes local food, traditional cooking, and sustainable agriculture.
The distance that food travels from the farm to the consumer.
Providing information to consumers about the carbon footprint of a product.
The practice of purchasing products and services that are considered environmentally friendly.
The practice of purchasing products and services that are produced in a way that is ethical and sustainable.
Ways of living that minimize environmental impacts and promote social equity.
Education that aims to increase knowledge and awareness about environmental issues.
Scientific research conducted, in whole or in part, by amateur or nonprofessional scientists.
The practice of providing time and effort to a cause without financial compensation.
The act of pleading or arguing in favor of something, such as a cause or policy.
The act of attempting to influence government policy.
Action taken to influence government policy.
Movements that originate from the local level.
Loosely organized but sustained campaigns in support of a social goal, typically either the implementation or the prevention of a change in society's structure or values.
The practice of achieving goals through symbolic protests, civil disobedience, economic or political noncooperation, satyagraha, or other methods, without using violence.
The refusal to comply with certain laws or to pay taxes and fines, as a peaceful form of political protest.
A form of political action that seeks to disrupt the status quo and achieve specific goals, often through nonviolent means.
Protests by students and others demanding action to address climate change.

A global environmental movement with the stated aim of using nonviolent civil disobedience to compel government action to avoid tipping points in the climate system, biodiversity loss, and the risk of social and ecological collapse.
A youth-led movement advocating for action to address climate change.
Actions taken to protect the environment.
Actions taken to promote social justice.
Actions taken to influence government policy.
Investing in companies whose business practices align with one's values.
Selling stocks, bonds, or other investment funds that are related to fossil fuel companies.
Investing in companies or projects that are designed to generate social and environmental impact alongside financial returns.
A company's commitment to operate in an ethical and sustainable manner.
Business practices that minimize environmental impacts and promote social equity.
The practice of marketing products and services that are considered environmentally friendly.
A trading partnership, based on dialogue, transparency and respect, that seeks greater equity in international trade.
Ensuring that the products and services you buy are produced in a way that is ethical and sustainable.
The management of the flow of goods, data, and finances related to a product or service, from the procurement of raw materials to the delivery of the final product to the consumer.
A systematic analysis of the environmental impacts of a product or service throughout its entire life cycle.
An economic system aimed at eliminating waste and the continual use of resources.
The collection, transport, processing, recycling, or disposal of waste materials.
A philosophy that encourages the redesign of resource life cycles so that all products are reused.
Converting waste materials into new products.
The biological decomposition of organic waste.
The breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms in the absence of oxygen.
The burning of waste materials.
The disposal of waste materials in landfills.
A hierarchical approach to waste management that prioritizes reducing waste generation, reusing materials, and recycling materials.
Reducing or eliminating pollution at its source.
Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of
The loose upper layer of Earth's surface capable of supporting plant life.
The uppermost layer of soil, rich in organic matter and nutrients.
The layer of soil beneath the topsoil, typically less fertile.
The solid rock underlying soil and other loose material.
Decomposed organic matter in soil.
Soil composed of sand, silt, and clay in relatively equal proportions.
Soil particles that are very small and tightly packed.
Soil particles that are large and feel gritty.
Soil particles intermediate in size between sand and clay.
The proportion of sand, silt, and clay in a soil.
The arrangement of soil particles into aggregates.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of soil.
The process of soil being carried away by wind or water.
The breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller particles.
The underlying geological material from which soil is formed.
A distinct layer within a soil profile.
A vertical section of soil showing the different horizons.
The process of water carrying dissolved substances down through the soil.
Minerals and organic substances essential for plant growth.
Decomposed plant and animal material in soil.
The process of soil becoming densely packed, reducing pore space.
The ability of soil to allow water to flow through it.
The ability of soil to hold water.
Practices used to protect soil from erosion and degradation.
A crop planted primarily to protect and improve the soil.
A farming method that avoids tilling the soil.
The process of salt accumulation in soil.
The process of fertile land becoming desert.
Decomposed organic matter used as fertilizer.
Natural or synthetic substances added to soil to provide nutrients.
A symbiotic association between fungi and plant roots.
The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into usable forms by bacteria.
Bacteria, fungi, and other organisms living in soil.
The removal of excess water from soil.
The ability of water to move upwards in soil against gravity.
The soil's ability to hold and exchange positively charged nutrients.
The process of water soaking into the soil.
Removal of a thin layer of soil by flowing water.
Removal of soil creating deep channels.
Removal of soil by wind.
Soil saturation with water, inhibiting plant growth.
Shaping land into level steps to control erosion.
Plowing along the contour lines of a field to reduce erosion.
Planting different crops in alternating strips to prevent erosion.
Planting different crops in a sequence to improve soil health.
Material added to soil to improve its physical or chemical properties.
A cover crop that is plowed into the soil to add nutrients.
Precipitation containing acidic pollutants that can damage soil.
Decline in soil quality, often caused by human activities.
The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem.
The zone of soil immediately surrounding plant roots.
The surface layer of soil bound by grass roots.
A layer of material applied to the soil surface to retain moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature.
Soil with a high concentration of sodium.
A soil-forming process resulting in distinct soil horizons characterized by leaching of iron and aluminum.
A soil-forming process resulting in the accumulation of calcium carbonate.
A soil-forming process common in tropical regions leading to the formation of iron-rich soils.
A systematic examination, description, classification, and mapping of soils in a given area.
The preparation of land for growing crops.
Charcoal used as a soil amendment.
Partially decayed plant matter found in bogs and marshes.
The ability of soil aggregates to resist breakdown.
Land suitable for cultivation.
Benefits that humans receive from ecosystems, including soil.
A layer of loose, heterogeneous superficial deposits covering solid rock.
The process of air exchange in the soil.
Growing plants without soil, using water and nutrient solutions.
Growing plants in an air or mist environment without soil.
The practice of eating soil or clay.
Diseases caused by pathogens living in the soil.
Cleaning up contaminated soil.
The ability of a soil to support plant growth.
Nutrients required for plant growth that plants cannot synthesize.
Nutrients required in large quantities by plants.
Nutrients required in small quantities by plants.
Yellowing of leaves due to nutrient deficiencies.
Death of plant tissue.
Reduced growth rate of plants.
The level at which a substance becomes poisonous to plants.
The movement and exchange of organic and inorganic matter back into the production of living matter.
The process by which bacteria convert nitrates into nitrogen gas.
The conversion of organic nitrogen into ammonia.
The conversion of ammonia into nitrites and then nitrates.
Naturally occurring, inorganic solids with a definite chemical composition and crystalline structure.
A naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals.
Rocks formed from cooled magma or lava.
Rocks formed from accumulated sediments.
Rocks formed from other rocks that have been changed by heat and pressure.
A farming system that relies on practices such as crop rotation, green manure, compost, and biological pest control.
A farming system that relies on synthetic fertilizers and pesticides.
Farming practices that meet current needs without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
Tillage practices that leave at least 30% of the soil surface covered with crop residue.
Tillage practices that leave 15-30% of the soil surface covered with crop residue.
Tillage practices that involve plowing and other intensive operations.
A small gully that forms and disappears with each rainfall event.
The process of soil particles settling out of water or air.
A vegetated area that slows water runoff and traps sediment and pollutants.
A natural or constructed channel that is shaped or graded and established in suitable vegetation for the stable conveyance of runoff.
A temporary barrier made of fabric that is used to trap sediment.
A temporary covering made of fabric that is used to protect soil from erosion.
The use of living plant materials to stabilize soil and control erosion.
The process of replanting vegetation on disturbed soil.
The use of plants to remove pollutants from soil.
The use of fungi to remove pollutants from soil.
The use of microorganisms to remove pollutants from soil.
Metallic elements with a high density that can be toxic to plants and animals.
Chemicals used to kill pests.
Chemicals used to kill weeds.
Chemicals used to kill fungi.
Chemicals used to kill insects.
Organic chemicals that are resistant to degradation.
Organic chemicals that evaporate easily.
A measure of the total amount of petroleum-based compounds in soil.
A group of persistent organic pollutants that were used in electrical equipment.
A group of highly toxic chemicals that are produced as byproducts of industrial processes.
A group of highly toxic chemicals that are produced as byproducts of industrial processes.
A naturally occurring mineral fiber that can cause lung cancer.
A radioactive gas that can seep into homes from the soil.
A site where waste is disposed of by burying it in the ground.
A contaminated site that is eligible for cleanup under the Superfund program.
A contaminated site that may be redeveloped or reused.
A preliminary assessment of a property's environmental condition.
A more detailed assessment of a property's environmental condition that may involve soil sampling.
A detailed assessment of a property's environmental condition and may involve remediation.
A federal agency responsible for protecting human health and the environment.
A state agency responsible for protecting human health and the environment.
The process of analyzing soil samples to determine their properties.
A government agency that provides educational programs and services to farmers.
A federal agency that provides technical assistance to farmers and landowners on conservation practices.
An international day celebrated on December 5th to raise awareness of the importance of soil.
A year declared by the United Nations to raise awareness of the importance of soil.
The uppermost layer of soil, rich in organic matter and nutrients.
The layer of soil beneath the topsoil, less fertile and with less organic matter.
The solid rock layer that lies beneath the soil layers.
Decomposed organic matter in soil, contributing to fertility and water retention.
The breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller particles.
The process by which soil and rock particles are transported by wind, water, or ice.
The proportion of sand, silt, and clay particles in a soil.
The arrangement of soil particles into aggregates or peds.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of the soil.
The ability of a soil to supply nutrients essential for plant growth.
A soil composed of a balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay.
Large soil particles that provide good drainage.
Medium-sized soil particles with good water-holding capacity.
Small soil particles that retain water and nutrients well.
A vertical section of soil showing the different layers or horizons.
A distinct layer within a soil profile.
The underlying geological material from which soil is formed.
The process by which water carries dissolved minerals and nutrients downward through the soil.
The compression of soil particles, reducing pore space and infiltration.
The movement and exchange of organic and inorganic matter back into the production of living matter.
Essential elements required by plants in large quantities (e.g., nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium).
Essential elements required by plants in small quantities (e.g., iron, zinc, copper).
Practices used to protect soil from erosion and degradation.
A crop planted primarily to protect the soil from erosion and improve soil health.
Plowing across a slope following its elevation contour lines.
Creating level platforms on steep slopes to reduce erosion.
A farming practice that avoids plowing, leaving crop residue on the surface.
The accumulation of salts in the soil, often due to irrigation.
The saturation of soil with water, inhibiting plant growth.
Microscopic organisms, such as bacteria and fungi, that live in the soil.
A symbiotic association between a fungus and the roots of a plant.
The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into a form usable by plants.
The conversion of nitrates in the soil into gaseous nitrogen.
A soil-forming process resulting in acid soils with a leached surface horizon and an accumulation of iron and aluminum in the subsoil.
A soil-forming process in hot, wet climates resulting in the formation of soils rich in iron and aluminum oxides.
A soil-forming process resulting in the accumulation of calcium carbonate in the soil.
The mass of dry soil per unit volume.
The percentage of total soil volume that is pore space.
The ability of water to move upward through soil against gravity.
The point at which plants can no longer extract water from the soil and begin to wilt.
The amount of water held in the soil after excess water has drained away.
The amount of water in the soil that is available for plant uptake.
Materials added to soil to improve its physical or chemical properties.
Decomposed organic matter used as a soil amendment.
Animal waste used as a fertilizer and soil amendment.
Natural or synthetic materials added to soil to provide nutrients for plant growth.
The decline in soil quality, often due to erosion, pollution, or unsustainable land management practices.
The measure of the total amount of soluble salts in soil.
The measure of the amount of sodium in soil relative to other cations. A high sodicity can cause soil dispersion.
The zone of soil surrounding plant roots, characterized by intense biological activity.
The process by which microorganisms in the soil consume organic matter and release carbon dioxide.
Using biological organisms to remove pollutants from soil.
The study of the effects of toxic substances on ecosystems, including soil.
The process of delineating different soil types on a map.
The systematic examination, description, classification, and mapping of soils in an area.
The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.
Any material that is derived from living organisms, including plant and animal residues, in the soil.
A cluster of soil particles held together by organic matter, clay, or other binding agents.
Lacking free oxygen. Important for processes in saturated soils.
Requiring free oxygen.
The study of organisms living in the soil and their role in soil processes.
The condition of having a pH greater than 7.
The condition of having a pH less than 7.
The total capacity of a soil to hold exchangeable cations.
The percentage of a soil's CEC occupied by base cations (calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium).
The ability of a soil to resist changes in pH.
The process by which water enters the soil.
The downward movement of water through soil.
Water that flows over the land surface without infiltrating into the soil.
The upper level of the saturated zone in the ground.
Liquid waste or sewage discharged into a river or the sea.
Any material added to the soil to improve its physical, chemical, or biological properties.
The vegetative part of a fungus, consisting of a network of fine white filaments.
A multicellular structure on which spore-producing structures, such as basidia or asci, are born. A mushroom is an example of a sporocarp.
Small roundworms that live in soil and can be beneficial or harmful to plants.
A group of bacteria that resemble fungi and are important in decomposing organic matter.
A process by which the soil is pressed together, reducing pore space and infiltration.
Breakdown of soil aggregates, leading to a loss of soil structure.
Measures taken to prevent or reduce soil erosion.
The practice of growing different crops in a sequence on the same land.
Growing two or more crops simultaneously in the same field.
Integrating trees and shrubs into agricultural systems.
Planting seeds directly into undisturbed soil, without tilling.
Tillage systems that minimize soil disturbance.
A layer of organic or inorganic material applied to the soil surface to conserve moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature.
A row of trees or shrubs planted to protect crops or soil from wind erosion.
An area of vegetation planted along waterways or other sensitive areas to filter pollutants and prevent erosion.
Analyzing a soil sample to determine its nutrient content, pH, and other properties.
A soil with a high concentration of soluble salts.
A soil with a high concentration of sodium ions.
The detachment and transport of soil particles by water.
The detachment and transport of soil particles by wind.
The removal of a thin layer of soil from a large area.
The formation of deep channels or gullies by flowing water.
The formation of small channels or rills by flowing water.
The downslope movement of a mass of soil, rock, and debris.
The slow, gradual downslope movement of soil.
A type of landslide characterized by the rotational movement of a mass of soil or rock.
A rapid flow of water, soil, rock, and organic debris.
The total mass of living organisms in a given area or volume.
The part of a plant that grows underground and absorbs water and nutrients.
The parts of a plant that remain after harvest.
A farming system that relies on natural methods of pest control and soil fertility.
Farming practices that are environmentally sound, economically viable, and socially responsible.
Any material added to the soil to improve its physical, chemical, or biological properties.
Excessive richness of nutrients in a lake or other body of water, frequently due to runoff from the land, which causes a dense growth of plant life and death of animal life from lack of oxygen.
The study of ecological processes in agricultural systems.
Using plants to remove pollutants from soil.
Using worms to decompose organic waste and produce compost.
A crop that is grown specifically to be plowed back into the soil to improve its fertility.
Plants that have nodules on their roots containing nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
Bacteria that live in the roots of legumes and fix nitrogen.
Diseases caused by pathogens living in the soil.
Organic horizon, consisting of leaf litter and other organic matter on the surface.
Topsoil, rich in humus and minerals.
Eluviated horizon, leached of clay, iron, and aluminum oxides.
Subsoil, accumulation of clay, iron, and aluminum oxides.
Weathered parent material.
The systematic arrangement of soils into groups based on their properties.
A comprehensive soil classification system used in the United States.
Young soils with weakly developed horizons.
Soils formed from volcanic ash.
Soils found in permafrost regions.
Organic soils, such as peat and muck.
Acid soils with a spodic horizon, typically found in coniferous forests.
Highly weathered soils with a high content of iron and aluminum oxides, typically found in tropical regions.
Clay-rich soils that shrink and swell with changes in moisture content.
Soils found in arid regions.
Highly weathered soils with a low base saturation.
Grassland soils with a thick, dark A horizon.
Moderately weathered soils with a medium base saturation.
Very young soils with little or no horizon development.
The ability of a soil to hold water.
The rate at which water moves through soil.
The visual appearance of soil, used as an indicator of soil properties.
The ability of a soil to drain excess water.
The physical condition of the soil as it relates to its suitability for plant growth.
The amount of soil lost per unit area per unit time.
The process by which soil particles are deposited in waterways.
Pollution that comes from a specific, identifiable source.
Pollution that comes from a diffuse source, such as agricultural runoff.
Conservation practices designed to reduce pollution and protect soil and water resources.
The maximum amount of a pollutant that a water body can receive and still meet water quality standards.
A United States federal law that regulates water pollution.
A map showing the distribution of different soil types in an area.
A detailed description of the horizons in a soil profile.
The use of soil information to predict soil behavior and suitability for various uses.
The process of determining the best use of land.
The integrated management of land and water resources in a watershed.
The benefits that humans derive from ecosystems, such as clean water, clean air, and fertile soil.
The process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon dioxide.
Actions taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Actions taken to adjust to the effects of climate change.
The ability of a system to recover from disturbance.
Meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
Sustaining soil resources for current and future generations.
A state in which the amount of healthy and productive land remains stable or increases.
The roles soil plays in supporting life and the environment.
The study of interactions between soil organisms and their environment.
The study of the physical features of the earth's surface and their relation to its geological structures.
Acquiring information about the Earth's surface without physical contact.
A computer system for capturing, storing, analyzing, and displaying geographic data.
The maximum amount of soil loss that can occur without affecting long-term soil productivity.
A written record of a farmer's decisions regarding land use and conservation practices.
A government program that provides financial assistance to farmers for implementing conservation practices.
A legal agreement that restricts the use of land to protect its conservation values.
A non-profit organization that works to conserve land.
Citizens collecting data to assess environmental conditions.

The fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, color, national origin, or income, with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and policies.
The process of involving people who have an interest in a decision or project.
A systematic process for continually improving management policies and practices by learning from the outcomes of operational programs.
A farming management concept based on observing and responding to inter and intra-field variation.
Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions.

flashcards.term: The World Reference Base for Soil Resources (WRB)
flashcards.definition: An international soil classification system.
A project to create a digital map of the world's soils.
A system for grouping soils according to their suitability for different uses.
Land that has the best combination of physical and chemical characteristics for producing food crops.
Land that is not prime farmland but is still suitable for agricultural production.
The uncontrolled expansion of urban areas.
A surface that does not allow water to infiltrate into the soil.
Practices designed to control the volume and flow of stormwater runoff.
A network of natural and semi-natural areas designed to provide ecosystem services.
An approach to land development that aims to minimize environmental impact.
A rating system for sustainable land development and landscape design.
A property whose expansion, redevelopment, or reuse may be complicated by the presence or potential presence of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant.
A contaminated site that is designated for cleanup under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA).
A study to determine the potential environmental impacts of a proposed project.
A detailed report that assesses the environmental impacts of a proposed project.
The process of obtaining permission from a government agency to conduct an activity that may affect the environment.
Adhering to environmental laws and regulations.
Actions taken to ensure compliance with environmental laws and regulations.
The systematic collection of data to assess environmental conditions.
The process of examining data to identify patterns and trends.
Communicating the results of environmental monitoring and data analysis.
Educating the public about environmental issues.
Involving the community in environmental decision-making.
Working together to achieve common environmental goals.
Developing new technologies and approaches to address environmental challenges.
The most effective technology available for controlling pollution.
A method for evaluating the environmental impacts of a product or process throughout its entire life cycle.
A framework for managing an organization's environmental impacts.
An international standard for environmental management systems.
A systematic evaluation of an organization's environmental performance.
The process of investigating a property to identify potential environmental liabilities.
The process of identifying and evaluating potential environmental risks.
The process of taking steps to reduce environmental risks.
The process of cleaning up contaminated sites.
The process of restoring damaged ecosystems.
Providing payment for environmental damage.
Reducing or eliminating pollution at the source.
Reducing the amount of waste generated.
Processing waste materials into new products.
Decomposing organic waste into compost.
Burning waste materials.
Disposing of waste in landfills.
Waste that is dangerous or potentially harmful to human health or the environment.
Non-liquid waste materials.
Water that has been used and contaminated.
Water that runs off of surfaces during rain events.
Water that is safe to drink.
Water that is found in lakes, rivers, and streams.
Water that is found underground.
An area of land that drains into a common waterway.
An area of land that is saturated with water for at least part of the year.
A partially enclosed coastal body of water where freshwater from rivers and streams mixes with saltwater from the ocean.
The area where the land meets the sea.
The ocean and its ecosystems.
The layer of gases surrounding the Earth.
The average weather conditions in a region over a long period of time.
The gradual increase in the Earth's average surface temperature.
A gas that traps heat in the atmosphere.
The total amount of greenhouse gases emitted by an individual, organization, event, or product.
Energy that comes from sources that are naturally replenished.
Using less energy to perform the same task.
A legal agreement that protects land from development.
A non-profit organization that works to conserve land.
Educating people about environmental issues.
Scientific research conducted by amateur scientists.
Donating time and effort to environmental causes.
Supporting environmental policies and regulations.
Moral principles that guide our relationship with the environment.
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
An economic system aimed at minimizing waste and making the most of resources.
Innovation inspired by nature.
A system of farming principles and practices that increases biodiversity, enriches soils, improves watersheds, and enhances ecosystem services.
The practice of producing food in vertically stacked layers, often indoors.
A system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish or other aquatic animals supplies nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water.
A method of growing plants without soil, using mineral nutrient solutions in water.
A system of growing plants in an air or mist environment without the use of soil or an aggregate medium.
Using solar radiation to control soilborne pests and diseases.
A charcoal-like material produced from biomass that can be used as a soil amendment.
The release of organic compounds from plant roots into the surrounding soil.
The chemical inhibition of one plant by another, due to the release of substances acting as germination or growth inhibitors.
A community of living organisms on the soil surface in arid and semi-arid ecosystems.
The uppermost layer of a soil profile that is darkened by organic matter.
A diagnostic horizon that occurs below the epipedon.
A soil moisture regime that is dry for at least half of the growing season.
A soil moisture regime that is moist during the growing season but dry for a significant portion of the year.
A soil moisture regime that is moist throughout the year.
A soil moisture regime that is extremely wet.
A soil moisture regime that is dry during the summer and moist during the winter.
A soil temperature regime that is very cold.
A soil temperature regime that is cold.
A soil temperature regime that is moderate.
A soil temperature regime that is warm.
A soil temperature regime that is very warm.
prefix meaning nearly uniform or equal throughout.
Soil moisture regime with prolonged saturation, resulting in reducing conditions.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of exchangeable sodium.
A subsurface horizon with an accumulation of clay.
A subsurface horizon with low activity clays and a low cation exchange capacity.
A subsurface horizon characterized by the accumulation of illuvial humus and aluminum oxides, with or without iron oxides.
A highly weathered subsurface horizon that is rich in iron and aluminum oxides and has a low cation exchange capacity.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of calcium carbonate.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of gypsum.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of soluble salts.
A thin, dark-reddish to black, iron and/or manganese-cemented layer that forms in wet, acid, sandy soils.
A dense, brittle subsurface horizon that restricts root growth and water movement.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by silica and is very hard and brittle.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by calcium carbonate and is very hard and indurated.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by gypsum and is very hard and indurated.
A subsurface horizon that is dense and has very few pores.
A buried soil that formed in the past.
A sequence of soils that occur on different topographic positions.
A sequence of soils with different characteristics that occur on a slope.
A subdivision of a soil series that takes into account surface texture, slope, erosion, and other characteristics.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups soil series with similar physical and chemical properties.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups soil families with similar horizons and properties.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups great groups with similar moisture and temperature regimes.
The highest level of classification in soil taxonomy.
A delineation on a soil map that represents a single soil type or a combination of soil types.
Acquiring information about an object or area from a distance, typically using satellites or aircraft.
The amount of light that is reflected by a surface at different wavelengths.
The process of assigning pixels in an image to different classes.
A measure of vegetation greenness based on the difference between near-infrared and red light reflectance.
Using computer models to predict soil erosion rates.
Developing a plan to manage nutrients in a way that protects water quality.
A strategy for managing pests that minimizes the use of pesticides.
A system of farming in which all machinery traffic is confined to permanent wheel tracks.
Applying water to crops in a way that minimizes water waste.
Applying inputs, such as fertilizer and pesticides, at different rates depending on the specific needs of the crop.
Creating a map of crop yields based on data collected by yield monitors.
A satellite-based navigation system that provides location information.
A computer system for capturing, storing, analyzing, and displaying geographic data.
Acquiring information about an object or area from a distance, typically using satellites or aircraft.
Unmanned aircraft that can be used to collect aerial imagery and data.
Devices that can be used to measure soil properties, such as moisture content and nutrient levels.
The process of examining large datasets to identify patterns and insights.
A type of artificial intelligence that allows computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.
The ability of a computer to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.
A network of physical devices, vehicles, and other items embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and network connectivity that enables these objects to collect and exchange data.
Storing and accessing data and software over the Internet.
Protecting computer systems and networks from cyberattacks.
The use of digital technologies to improve agricultural production.
Using digital technologies to make farming more efficient and sustainable.
The integration of digital technologies into all aspects of agriculture.
Sustaining soil resources for current and future generations.
A state in which the amount of healthy and productive land remains stable or increases.
A set of 17 goals adopted by the United Nations to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all.
The benefits that humans derive from ecosystems.
The process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon dioxide.
Actions taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Actions taken to adjust to the effects of climate change.
The ability of a system to recover from disturbance.
Meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
The roles soil plays in supporting life and the environment.
The study of interactions between soil organisms and their environment.
The study of the physical features of the earth's surface and their relation to its geological structures.
Acquiring information about the Earth's surface without physical contact.
A computer system for capturing, storing, analyzing, and displaying geographic data.
The maximum amount of soil loss that can occur without affecting long-term soil productivity.
A written record of a farmer's decisions regarding land use and conservation practices.
A government program that provides financial assistance to farmers for implementing conservation practices.
A legal agreement that restricts the use of land to protect its conservation values.
A non-profit organization that works to conserve land.
Citizens collecting data to assess environmental conditions.

The fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, color, national origin, or income, with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and policies.
The process of involving people who have an interest in a decision or project.
A systematic process for continually improving management policies and practices by learning from the outcomes of operational programs.
A farming management concept based on observing and responding to inter and intra-field variation.
Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions.

Innovation inspired by nature.
A system of farming principles and practices that increases biodiversity, enriches soils, improves watersheds, and enhances ecosystem services.
The practice of producing food in vertically stacked layers, often indoors.
A system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish or other aquatic animals supplies nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water.
A method of growing plants without soil, using mineral nutrient solutions in water.
A system of growing plants in an air or mist environment without the use of soil or an aggregate medium.
Using solar radiation to control soilborne pests and diseases.
A charcoal-like material produced from biomass that can be used as a soil amendment.
The release of organic compounds from plant roots into the surrounding soil.
The chemical inhibition of one plant by another, due to the release of substances acting as germination or growth inhibitors.
A community of living organisms on the soil surface in arid and semi-arid ecosystems.
The uppermost layer of a soil profile that is darkened by organic matter.
A diagnostic horizon that occurs below the epipedon.
A soil moisture regime that is dry for at least half of the growing season.
A soil moisture regime that is moist during the growing season but dry for a significant portion of the year.
A soil moisture regime that is moist throughout the year.
A soil moisture regime that is extremely wet.
A soil moisture regime that is dry during the summer and moist during the winter.
A soil temperature regime that is very cold.
A soil temperature regime that is cold.
A soil temperature regime that is moderate.
A soil temperature regime that is warm.
A soil temperature regime that is very warm.
prefix meaning nearly uniform or equal throughout.
Soil moisture regime with prolonged saturation, resulting in reducing conditions.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of exchangeable sodium.
A subsurface horizon with an accumulation of clay.
A subsurface horizon with low activity clays and a low cation exchange capacity.
A subsurface horizon characterized by the accumulation of illuvial humus and aluminum oxides, with or without iron oxides.
A highly weathered subsurface horizon that is rich in iron and aluminum oxides and has a low cation exchange capacity.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of calcium carbonate.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of gypsum.
A subsurface horizon that has an accumulation of soluble salts.
A thin, dark-reddish to black, iron and/or manganese-cemented layer that forms in wet, acid, sandy soils.
A dense, brittle subsurface horizon that restricts root growth and water movement.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by silica and is very hard and brittle.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by calcium carbonate and is very hard and indurated.
A subsurface horizon that is cemented by gypsum and is very hard and indurated.
A subsurface horizon that is dense and has very few pores.
A buried soil that formed in the past.
A sequence of soils that occur on different topographic positions.
A sequence of soils with different characteristics that occur on a slope.
A subdivision of a soil series that takes into account surface texture, slope, erosion, and other characteristics.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups soil series with similar physical and chemical properties.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups soil families with similar horizons and properties.
A category in soil taxonomy that groups great groups with similar moisture and temperature regimes.
The highest level of classification in soil taxonomy.
A delineation on a soil map that represents a single soil type or a combination of soil types.
